choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

  • Curve A shows linear relationship between PCO2 and Ventilation i.e hypercapnia (↑PCO2) → ↑ Ventilation
  • Curve B shows effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on Ventilation i.e when both Hypercapnia and Hypoxia (↑PCO2 & ↓O2) are present simultaneously but the pH is normal (unchanged)à slope of the curve also changes hence as a result curve becomes Steeper
  • Curve C shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e. when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are present simultaneously → not only the slope of the curve changes but also the Shift of Apneic Point (point denoting PCO2 Levels Below which apnea i.e stoppage of breathing occurs) is seen.
  • Curve D also shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (but in the question pH is Normal 7.35 ) on Ventilation i.e., when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are more severe à the slope of the curve will be more steeper with the Shift of Apneic Point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curve B represents the condition of simultaneous hypoxia and hypercapnia with normal pH, showing a steeper slope in the relationship between PCO2 and ventilation.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kartagener syndrome

 

 

Kartagener syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia with situs inversus, is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of symptoms: bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus. The provided image shows clear evidence of situs inversus (with the heart apex and stomach bubble on the right side) and bronchiectasis (dilated bronchi seen on the X-ray). These findings align perfectly with Kartagener syndrome.

 

In this image:

 

  • The heart apex is seen on the right side, confirming dextrocardia.
  • The stomach bubble is also on the right side, indicating situs inversus.
  • There are multifocal dilated bronchi, which are signs of bronchiectasis.

 

These findings together strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labelling error: While it is crucial to confirm that the X-ray is correctly labeled (i.e., left and right markers), in this case, the labeling is correct, and the findings of situs inversus, dextrocardia, and bronchiectasis are genuine.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, which would not present as dextrocardia or bronchiectasis. It is not consistent with the X-ray findings shown.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis can also present with bronchiectasis, but it does not typically involve situs inversus or dextrocardia, making this an incorrect option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis, often identified by observing the positions of the heart, stomach bubble, and bronchi on imaging.

questions.text: An 88-year-old male presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain. On physical examination, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115 bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72 mm of Hg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding.
  • Most sensitive X-ray: CXR-PA erect.
  • Most sensitive Ix: CECT with oral contrast.
  • Next step: Resuscitation with IV fluids, Exploratory laparotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: Involves air in the pleural space, not under the diaphragm. The clinical presentation and X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized pain and fever, but X-ray findings would be more consistent with an abscess formation rather than free air.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While it might present with abdominal pain and distension, free air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic finding unless there is a concurrent bowel perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumoperitoneum is a critical finding indicating a potential perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, requiring immediate assessment and surgical intervention. This diagnosis is supported by the presence of free air under the diaphragm seen on the X-ray.

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

This abnormal posturing is caused by tetanospasmin which is produced by clostridium tetani. It inhibits presynaptic GABA and glycine release.

 

 

Clostridium tetani is an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus with terminal round spore (drumstick appearance).

 

Tetanus is manifested by skeletal muscle spasms and autonomic nervous system disturbance. Tetanus only affects skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle function normally.

 

C. tetani produces two exotoxins–tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.

 

  1. Tetanolysin is a heat-labile, oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to the oxygen-labile hemolysins produced by C. perfringens, S. pyogenes, and S. pneumoniae. Tetanolysin damages otherwise viable tissue surrounding the infection and optimizes the conditions for bacterial multiplication.
  2. Tetanospasmin (or tetanus toxin) is a heat-labile, oxygen-stable, plasmid-coded neurotoxin responsible for disease manifestations. Tetanus neurotoxin is released upon cell lysis after bacterial growth under anaerobic conditions (e.g., in deep puncture wounds). It is antigenic and is specifically neutralized by its antitoxin. Its toxoid form is used for vaccine preparation.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin-

 

Tetanus toxin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors present on motor nerve terminals which results in toxin internalization.

 

Following internalization, tetanus toxin gets transported in a retrograde way from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system by retrograde axonal transport. When tetanus toxin reaches inhibitory neuron terminals, it prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

 

Incubation period of tetanus is about 6-10 days.

 

 

Clinical features - Patients have prolonged muscle spasms of both flexor and extensor muscles. Patients with tetanus have spastic muscle contractions, difficulty opening the jaw (called lockjaw, “trismus”), a characteristic smile called “risus sardonicus” and contractions of back muscles resulting in backward arching (Opisthotonos position). Patients are extremely irritable, and tetanic seizures develop, brought about by violent, painful muscle contractions following some minor stimulus, such as noise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presynaptic inhibition of Ach receptors: This mechanism is not involved in the action of tetanospasmin. It is more relevant to the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option C. Postsynaptic inhibition of GABA: This is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release: This describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, which prevents the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

choices.text: It takes 4 -5 years for gall stones to develop
Splenectomy is not protective against developing gall stones
At least 25 % cases have a family history of hereditary spherocytosis
Increase in MCH is pathognomonic of HS

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 25 % cases have a family history of  hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Atleast 25% cases of HS show familial inheritance since it is inherited as AD pattern more commonly.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It takes 4 -5 years for gall stones to develop: Gall stones typically develop in individuals with HS around 20–25 years of age, not within 4-5 years.

 

Option B. Splenectomy is not protective against developing gall stones: Splenectomy is a treatment option for HS and is protective against the development of certain complications, including hemolysis-related gallstones.

 

Option D. Increase in MCH is pathognomonic of HS: High MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is a characteristic finding in HS, but it is not pathognomonic (exclusively diagnostic) of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

At least 25% of cases of hereditary spherocytosis have a family history, reflecting its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1195, 1196

questions.text: Intermittent dose of Parathyroid hormone causes risk of:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

  • Intermittent doses of parathyroid hormone (PTH), specifically recombinant human PTH (teriparatide), are used in the treatment of osteoporosis and are associated with several risks and benefits.
  • Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been associated with PTH therapy, but this risk is primarily a concern with long-term continuous exposure rather than intermittent dosing.
  • Mechanism: 
    • Long-term continuous PTH exposure has been shown to increase the risk of osteosarcoma in studies.
    • This is due to PTH's effects on bone remodeling and the potential stimulation of abnormal bone cell proliferation.
  • Teriparatide (intermittent PTH) is used for osteoporosis and involves daily injections of 20mcg for a limited period (usually up to 2 years).
  • Clinical trials and long-term studies have not shown a definitive increase in osteosarcoma risk with this intermittent therapy, but caution is advised as osteosarcoma is a rare complication of intermittent PTH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subtrochanteric Atypical Fracture: Subtrochanteric atypical fractures are a known risk associated with long-term bisphosphonate therapy, not intermittent PTH therapy. Bisphosphonates work by inhibiting bone resorption, which can lead to the accumulation of micro-damage in bones. Over time, this may result in atypical femoral fractures, including subtrochanteric fractures, often with minimal trauma.

 

Option C. Net Loss of Bone Mass: Net loss of bone mass is not a typical outcome of intermittent PTH therapy. Intermittent PTH therapy generally leads to an increase in bone mass and improves bone density, especially when used in conjunction with other osteoporosis treatments. PTH stimulates osteoblast activity, which increases bone formation.

 

Option D. Osteonecrosis of Jaw: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a condition primarily associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates and other anti-resorptive therapies, not with intermittent PTH therapy. Osteonecrosis of the jaw is a severe condition where the jawbone becomes necrotic due to impaired blood supply, often linked to the suppression of bone resorption. This risk is notably higher with intravenous bisphosphonates and is associated with dental procedures or trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma have indicated a potential risk with continuous and intermittent PTH administration, though it is rarely seen complication of intermittent PTH therapy.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to ENT OPD with severe dysphagia of recent onset and muffled voice. On examination, a cherry red swollen epiglottis was seen behind the tongue. On X-ray, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The child presents with severe dysphagia, a muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis, which are classic signs of acute epiglottitis. The X-ray shows the characteristic "thumb sign," indicating a swollen epiglottis. Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention. The child will typically sit in the tripod position to help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Also known as croup, this condition typically presents with a barking cough and stridor. The X-ray shows the "steeple sign," which is not seen here.

 

Option C. Acute laryngitis: Acute laryngitis involves inflammation of the vocal cords, leading to hoarseness, but does not typically cause severe dysphagia or a swollen epiglottis.

 

Option D. Syphilis larynx: Syphilis affecting the larynx is rare and presents with different symptoms, such as hoarseness or a sore throat, rather than an acute swollen epiglottis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute epiglottitis presents with severe dysphagia, muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis. The "thumb sign" on X-ray is a characteristic finding, and immediate medical intervention is necessary.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: Ottawa Charter includes all except: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potentiate

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion, established in 1986, outlines five key action areas essential for health promotion: building healthy public policy, creating supportive environments, strengthening community action, developing personal skills, and reorienting health services.

 

In addition to these action areas, the Ottawa Charter emphasizes three fundamental strategies for health promotion: advocate, enable, and mediate. These strategies are aimed at fostering conditions that promote health and well-being, empowering individuals and communities, and facilitating partnerships among various sectors to achieve health goals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advocate: Advocacy is a core strategy of the Ottawa Charter aimed at creating conditions conducive to health by influencing public policy and resource allocation.

 

Option B. Enable: Enabling involves empowering people to achieve their fullest health potential by providing equitable access to resources and opportunities.

 

Option D. Mediate: Mediation focuses on coordinating actions among various sectors and stakeholders to resolve conflicts and achieve consensus for health promotion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion includes the strategies of advocate, enable, and mediate, but does not include potentiate.

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase contrast microscopy

 

Phase-contrast microscopy (PCM) is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations.

 

Contrast is improved by using the difference in thickness or refractive index of structures within and around the cell. Difference in intensity of light is created as rays pass through varied refractive indices and produces contrast thus making the structures within the cells and its surroundings clearly visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Option C. The electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image, unlike the optical microscope that uses visible light to magnify images.

 

Option D. Polarized microscopy is used to visualize the intracellular structures using differences in birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria by converting phase shifts into brightness changes.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is characterized by the triad of dementia, gait disturbance (typically apraxia or magnetic gait), and urinary incontinence. This condition often involves enlargement of the cerebral ventricles due to cerebrospinal fluid accumulation, which can exert pressure on surrounding brain structures, particularly affecting the frontal lobes responsible for cognitive and urinary control. The clinical presentation aligns well with the symptoms described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: This condition often presents with prominent personality changes and language difficulties rather than the classic triad seen in NPH. Falls are less commonly associated with this form of dementia in its early stages.

 

Option C. Parkinson disease: Typically presents with motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While dementia can occur in later stages, it is not typically accompanied by urinary incontinence and would not explain the early presence of falls as the primary symptom.

 

Option D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: Known for rapid progression of neurological symptoms including dementia, myoclonus (sudden muscle spasms), and significant motor dysfunction. It progresses much faster than what is typically seen in NPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction

 

Reference - Harrison/Dementia/Chap 434

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following nutrients can lead to delayed wound healing? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including DNA synthesis, cell division, and protein synthesis, all of which are vital for wound healing. Zinc is a cofactor for numerous enzymes, including matrix metalloproteinases, which are involved in the remodeling of extracellular matrix during wound healing. A deficiency in zinc impairs these processes, leading to delayed wound healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important for oxygen transport and cellular respiration, but its deficiency primarily leads to anemia and fatigue rather than directly causing delayed wound healing.

 

Option B. Magnesium: Magnesium is involved in many biochemical reactions, but its deficiency is more likely to cause muscle cramps, arrhythmias, and neuromuscular issues rather than significantly impacting wound healing.

 

Option D. Manganese: Manganese is a trace mineral important for bone formation and metabolism. While it is involved in enzyme function, its deficiency is less commonly linked to delayed wound healing compared to zinc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is required for functioning of matrix metalloproteases and so, required for proper wound healing. Any deficiency of zinc can lead to delayed wound healing.

questions.text: All of the following features are observed in pleomorphic adenoma except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineural invasion

 

Perineural invasion is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma.

 

 

Note - Perineural invasion is seen in malignant salivary gland tumors like adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myoepithelial cells: Present in pleomorphic adenomas, contributing to the tumor's mixed epithelial and mesenchymal characteristics.

 

Option B. Keratin pearls: While not typically a feature of pleomorphic adenomas, the presence of keratin can be associated with the epithelial component. However, keratin pearls are more characteristic of squamous cell carcinomas.

 

Option C. Chondroid differentiation: A hallmark of pleomorphic adenomas, where the tumor shows cartilaginous differentiation, often contributing to its benign nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Pleomorphic adenomas are characterized by a mixture of epithelial and mesenchymal components, including myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but they do not exhibit perineural invasion, which is more typical of malignant salivary gland tumors.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1436-1437

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime.

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police not under rank of sub inspector: Involved in criminal investigations but does not bear the onus of proof in civil negligence cases.

 

Option C. Magistrate: Presides over legal proceedings but does not bear the onus of proof.

 

Option D. Doctor: The doctor is the defendant in a negligence case and does not bear the initial burden of proof.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

 

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

choices.text: Occur in the early 20s, rare after 40
More common in males than females
HLA B27 is positive in >90%
MRI shows non-erosive joint widening

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Ankylosing Spondylitis are true except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRI shows non-erosive joint widening

 

MRI shows non-erosive joint widening: This is false. In ankylosing spondylitis, MRI typically shows evidence of erosions, joint narrowing, and inflammatory changes in the sacroiliac joints and spine. The disease can lead to ankylosis (fusion of the spine), syndesmophytes, and erosive arthropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. The correct statements regarding AS are:

 

Option A. Occur in the early 20s, rare after 40: Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents in young adults, often in their 20s, and is uncommon after the age of 40.

 

Option B. More common in males than females: AS is more prevalent in males, with a male-to-female ratio of approximately 3:1.

 

Option C. HLA B27 is positive in >90%: Over 90% of patients with AS test positive for the HLA-B27 gene, which is a significant marker for the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI findings in ankylosing spondylitis typically show erosive changes and joint narrowing, not non-erosive joint widening.

questions.text: What adverse effect is NOT seen with amiodarone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gynaecomastia

 

Explanation

 

Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication with a wide range of potential adverse effects. It is known to cause both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism due to its high iodine content.

 

Hypothyroidism occurs through the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, while hyperthyroidism occurs via the Jod-Basedow phenomenon. Additionally, amiodarone can cause pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pneumonitis and pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Gynaecomastia, which is the enlargement of male breast tissue, is not typically associated with amiodarone use. This condition is more commonly linked to medications that influence estrogen or androgen levels, which amiodarone does not significantly affect.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Can occur due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Can occur due to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon.

 

Option D. Pulmonary fibrosis: Known adverse effect of amiodarone, particularly with long-term use.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Amiodarone can cause both hypo- and hyperthyroidism as well as pulmonary fibrosis, but it does not cause gynaecomastia.

questions.text: A patient with reduced hemoglobin and gum bleeding presented to you. He has thrombocytopenia (platelet count 25,000/µl) elevated PT, and aPTT. Which of the following can the probable cause of his finding? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AML t (15;17)

 

The clinical presentation of reduced hemoglobin, gum bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and elevated PT and aPTT is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is associated with the t(15;17) translocation, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that commonly presents with DIC.

 

Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL):

 

  • Genetics: APL is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, which results in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This translocation disrupts the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene, leading to a block in myeloid differentiation at the promyelocyte stage.
  • Clinical Features: Patients often present with symptoms of bleeding (e.g., gum bleeding, bruising) due to DIC, which is a common complication of APL.
  • Laboratory Findings: Thrombocytopenia, elevated PT, and aPTT are consistent with DIC. The peripheral smear may show promyelocytes with Auer rods.
  • Management: APL is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), which induces differentiation of the malignant promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML t(8;21): Associated with AML with maturation, typically presenting with myeloblasts and not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option C. AML t(16;16): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils, also not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option D. AML with NPM1: NPM1 mutations are common in AML but do not specifically correlate with DIC or the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) associated with t(15;17) translocation commonly presents with DIC, characterized by thrombocytopenia and elevated coagulation times (PT and aPTT). DIC is due to release of procoagulant substances from the abnormal promyelocytes. Immediate identification and treatment with ATRA are crucial to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text:
A teenage girl presented with irregular cycles and increased facial hair. Her ovaries showed increased volume. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
  2. Anti-androgens
  3. Lifestyle modifications
  4. Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation of irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair, combined with increased ovarian volume, is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The first-line treatment options for PCOS typically include:

 

Anti-androgens (2): These medications help reduce symptoms related to excess androgens, such as facial hair and acne. Common examples include spironolactone.

 

Lifestyle modifications (3): These are crucial for managing PCOS. Weight loss and exercise can improve insulin sensitivity and help regulate menstrual cycles.

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (4): These are used to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce hyperandrogenism symptoms (like hirsutism), and provide endometrial protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (1): This is a surgical procedure used to treat PCOS, but it is generally considered a second-line treatment. It is typically performed when medical management fails to achieve the desired results.

 

Educational Objective:


The first-line treatments for PCOS include anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptive pills.

 

Ref: Page no 460, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text:
The drowned dead body of a young man found in the sea and was brought in for postmortem examination. Which of the following findings do you see in seawater drowning? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Hypernatremia
  2. Hyponatremia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Myocardial anoxia
  5. Hemodilution
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1 and 4   

 

 

Seawater Drowning Characteristics:

1. Hypernatremia: Seawater is hypertonic compared to the body fluids, leading to an increase in sodium levels in the blood.

4. Myocardial anoxia: Lack of oxygen due to drowning can lead to myocardial anoxia.

 

Fresh water drowning Vs Salt water Drowning

 

 

Other Options

 

2. Hyponatremia: Seen in freshwater drowning.

 

3. Hyperkalemia: Seen in freshwater drowning due to hemolysis.

 

5. Hemodilution: Seen in freshwater drowning due to absorption of water.

 

Educational Objective

 

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN FRESH WATER AND SALT WATER DROWNING

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be seen after one year of using lithium therapy ? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tardive dyskinesia

 

Tardive dyskinesia is least likely to be seen with lithium therapy. This condition is more typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic drugs, not lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tremors: Tremors are a common side effect of lithium, often observed in patients undergoing therapy.

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: Lithium use can lead to hypothyroidism, especially with long-term treatment.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Lithium can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by affecting kidney function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tardive dyskinesia is least likely to be seen with lithium therapy; it is more commonly associated with long-term use of antipsychotic drugs.

choices.text: US guided pig tail catheter drainage

questions.text: A man who had undergone cholecystectomy presented five days after the surgery with abdominal pain and tachycardia. WBC count is 13000 cells/mm3. US showed fluid collection 7x7 cm in right sub-hepatic space. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) US guided pig tail catheter drainage

 

Based on the information provided, the best next step in management for a patient who has undergone cholecystectomy and presented with abdominal pain, tachycardia, and a fluid collection in the sub-hepatic space, would be option B) US guided pigtail catheter drainage. Patient is likely to be suffering from post cholecystectomy acute bile duct injury.

 

This option involves the insertion of a small catheter through the skin into the fluid collection, guided by ultrasound imaging. The catheter is left in place to drain the fluid collection over several days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics and send home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a fluid collection in the sub-hepatic space. Drainage of collection is required to control sepsis.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy and re-exploration: This is a more invasive option and is typically reserved for cases where the pigtail catheter drainage is not successful.

 

Option D. ERCP: This may be done after collection is drained, to identify the site of injury, but won’t be the next step in management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of acute bile duct injury:

 

S- Sepsis control by pigtail catheter or surgical drainage

 

N- Nutrition

 

A- Anatomical delineation via MRCP/ERCP

 

P- Planned reconstruction

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon gamma release assay

 

TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

 

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

 

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 

T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.

 

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TrueNat TB: Incorrect, as this molecular test diagnoses TB and tests for rifampicin resistance using a sputum sample, not whole blood.

 

Option B. Gene Xpert: Incorrect, this is another molecular test that identifies TB and resistance to rifampicin but also uses sputum samples rather than whole blood.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect, as only the interferon gamma release assay is designed to be used with whole blood samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon gamma release assay is a valuable tool for diagnosing latent TB, particularly suitable for patients who may not be effectively diagnosed through traditional skin tests, offering a sensitive and specific method that utilizes whole blood to detect an immune response to TB antigens.

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

 

The patient presents with a clean-cut wound and has a history of receiving a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. Based on the guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, the appropriate management for this patient falls under the category where the patient has received a complete course of tetanus vaccination more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years ago.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:

 

 

CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Explanation

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene. It is characterized by tumors in three primary endocrine glands, known as the "three Ps":

 

  1. Parathyroid adenoma: Leading to primary hyperparathyroidism.
  2. Pituitary adenoma: Most commonly prolactinomas.
  3. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: Which can include gastrinomas, insulinomas, and non-functioning pancreatic tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parotid tumor and Option C. Renal cell carcinoma: Not associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: Associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, but not MEN 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 1 syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is associated with tumors in the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells, with parathyroid adenoma being a common manifestation.

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

 

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

 

The ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal is called the "Lisfranc ligament".

 

The Lisfranc ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone in the foot. It is named after Jacques Lisfranc, a French surgeon who described amputations through this region during the Napoleonic Wars. The Lisfranc joint complex also includes the articulation between the other cuneiform bones and the metatarsals, as well as the tarsometatarsal ligaments and interosseous ligaments. The Lisfranc ligament is important for maintaining stability of the midfoot and for transferring forces from the hindfoot to the forefoot during walking and running. Injuries to the Lisfranc joint can result in significant disability and may require surgery to repair or stabilize the joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chopart Ligament: Chopart's ligament is not a well-known ligament in the foot. The term "Chopart joint" typically refers to the midtarsal joint, which includes the articulation between the talus and navicular (talocalcaneonavicular joint) and the calcaneus and cuboid (calcaneocuboid joint). Ligaments associated with these joints help maintain their stability.

 

Option B. Spring Ligament: The spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone. It is a vital structure for supporting the arch of the foot and preventing its collapse.

 

Option D. Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial side of the ankle joint. It is a complex ligament that attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and connects to various tarsal bones, such as the talus, calcaneus, and navicular. The deltoid ligament plays a significant role in stabilizing the ankle joint and preventing excessive eversion (outward rolling) of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lisfranc ligament is specifically associated with the connection between the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a strong ligament that helps stabilize the midfoot and prevents dislocation of the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints. Injury to this ligament is commonly referred to as a Lisfranc injury, which can result from traumatic events like falls or sports injuries.

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

 

  • The capnograph shows a characteristic pattern known as the curare notch or curare cleft.
  • This pattern indicates spontaneous inspiratory effort by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • This occurs when the patient attempts to breathe against the ventilator cycle, causing a dip in the capnograph waveform.
  • The appropriate next step would be to paralyze the patient again by administering an additional dose of muscle relaxant to ensure proper synchronization with the ventilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal intubation: In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected. The waveform would be almost flat.

 

 

Option B. Inspiration with cardiac oscillations: Cardiac oscillations can appear on the capnograph as small oscillations or ripples on the expiratory plateau due to the beating of the heart causing minor fluctuations in airway pressure. This is not characterized by a distinct cleft or notch.

 

 

Option C. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm causes a "shark fin" appearance on the capnograph due to obstructed airflow and prolonged expiration. The waveform would show a slanted, rather than a squared-off, expiratory plateau.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A curare notch or cleft on a capnograph indicates spontaneous respiratory effort in a patient who is supposed to be fully ventilated under muscle relaxants, requiring re-administration of the muscle relaxant to ensure proper mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: Following an accident, a patient presented with an inability to flex the MCP joint and extend the IP joint of his hand. Which nerve is damaged here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

The patient’s symptoms of being unable to flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints suggest a problem with the lumbrical muscles. The lumbricals are responsible for these movements. Specifically, the third and fourth lumbrical muscles, which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the ring and little fingers, are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Damage to the ulnar nerve can result in a condition known as "claw hand," where these functions are compromised, leading to the inability to perform the described movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily controls the extension of the wrist and fingers, but not the flexion of the MCP joints or extension of the IP joints. Hence, it is not involved in this condition.

 

Option B. Anterior interosseous nerve: This is a branch of the median nerve, primarily responsible for the motor function of some of the deep muscles in the forearm but does not innervate the lumbricals. Therefore, it is not responsible for the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm, responsible for elbow flexion, but it does not play a role in the movement of the fingers or hand. Therefore, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the third and fourth lumbricals, which are essential for flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. Damage to this nerve can lead to the characteristic "claw hand" deformity.

choices.text: Acute tubular necrosis

questions.text: A patient was undergoing a hysteroscopic removal of a submucosal fibroid, in which a fluid deficit of 2000 mL is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario depicts case of fluid overload, due to which pulmonary edema can develop.

 

  • During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels.
  • Fluid deficit can be estimated by manual calculation or by use of an automated fluid management system.
  • When using hypotonic solutions (like glycine), the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000mL for healthy patients and 750mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
  • For normal saline, the maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2,500mL for healthy patients and 750mL for those with cardiovascular disease.
  • If excessive absorption of fluid occurs with a hypotonic fluid; obtain serum electrolytes and the patient should be evaluated for volume overload.
  • Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output.
  • Treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and managed in intensive care.
  • Fluid overload from normal saline can be managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute tubular necrosis: While fluid overload can contribute to kidney injury, acute tubular necrosis is not the immediate complication in this scenario.

 

Option B. DIC: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a serious condition involving abnormal blood clotting but is not directly related to fluid overload from hysteroscopy.

 

Option D. Thromboembolism: Thromboembolism involves blood clots traveling to various parts of the body but is not the immediate consequence of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluid overload during hysteroscopic surgery can lead to pulmonary edema as an immediate complication due to excessive absorption of uterine distension fluid.

questions.text: Match the following: (INCET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

1. Football sign: This sign is associated with pneumoperitoneum, where an accumulation of gas in the peritoneal cavity gives a silhouette resembling a football on X-ray images.

 

 

2. Rat tail sign: Typically seen in carcinoma of the esophagus, this sign describes the tapering of the esophageal lumen due to the tumor, resembling a rat’s tail..

 

 

3. String sign: Found in CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis), it refers to the appearance of a narrowed, elongated channel through the pylorus.

 

 

4. Inverted umbrella sign: This is seen in cases of TB (tuberculosis), particularly referring to the appearance of a contracted cecum and narrow ileocecal junction

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount

questions.text: The maximum thermic effect is seen with a meal which has? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Protein

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food.

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat: Fats have a moderate thermic effect, lower than proteins.

 

Option C. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have the lowest thermic effect.

 

Option D. Mixed meal having all 3 in equal amount: A mixed meal would have a combined thermic effect that is a weighted average of the individual macronutrient effects, which would be lower than that of a protein-only meal.

 

Real-world Observation: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal, especially during hot weather, individuals may feel hot and humid due to the increased heat production. Conversely, in cold weather, the same meal can provide a warming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum thermic effect is seen with protein-rich meals, as proteins require more energy for digestion, absorption, and metabolism compared to fats and carbohydrates.

choices.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution
Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries
To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution 

 

The standardized age mortality ratio serves as an indicator for the population's mortality rate adjusted to a standardized age distribution.

 

Standardization of Death Rates

 

  • While comparison of death rates of two populations, ‘crude death rate is not the right yardstick’, as age-compositions are different
  • Age-adjustment or age-standardization removes confounding effect of different age structures
  • Standardization may be direct or indirect
  • Standardization is carried out beginning by using a ‘Standard Population’

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution: Incorrect. Standardization typically adjusts for age, not sex.

 

Option C. Removal of bias due to different age group populations in different countries: Incorrect. This describes the purpose of age standardization, not the definition of standardized age mortality ratio.

 

Option D. To eliminate age structure of different countries: Incorrect. Age standardization accounts for, but does not eliminate, age structure differences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.

 

Additional Information

 

Types of Standardized Death Rates

 

Direct standardization:

 

  • Method:
    • Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied 
    • on a standard population
    • Total expected deaths calculated
    • Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • Feasibility:
    • Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
    • Availability of population in each age group

 

Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form

 

  • Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • Examples of indirect Standardization:

  • Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100

  • Life Table Analysis

  • Survival Analysis

questions.text: Transport of glucose on contraluminal side of intestinal cell is: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GLUT-2

 

GLUT-2 is involved in the transport of glucose on the basolateral (contraluminal) side of intestinal epithelial cells. After glucose is absorbed into these cells from the intestinal lumen via SGLT-1, it is then transported out into the bloodstream through GLUT-2. This transporter facilitates the exit of glucose from intestinal cells into the blood, playing a crucial role in postprandial glucose homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-1: SGLT-1 (Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporter 1) is located on the apical (luminal) side of intestinal epithelial cells. It is responsible for the active transport of glucose into the cell from the intestinal lumen, alongside sodium ions. This is the initial step in intestinal glucose absorption but not involved in the basolateral transport.

 

Option C. GLUT-5: GLUT-5 is a fructose transporter, predominantly found on the apical side of intestinal cells. It is responsible for the uptake of fructose from the intestinal lumen, not glucose transport on the contraluminal side.

 

Option D. GLUT-1: GLUT-1 is widely expressed in many tissues and is responsible for the basal uptake of glucose. It is not specifically involved in the transport of glucose on the contraluminal side of intestinal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter, which is primarily found on the basolateral (contra luminal) side of intestinal cells and is involved in the transport of glucose out of the enterocytes into the bloodstream.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 187

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid

 

  • The scenario described involves a young male patient who received a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure and subsequently became unresponsive with an unrecordable pulse.
  •  These are concerning signs of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), which can occur when local anesthetic drugs like bupivacaine enter the systemic circulation.
  • The best course of management for this patient is as follows:
  • This is the correct choice. Intralipid is a lipid emulsion used as the antidote for LAST.
  • It works by sequestering the local anesthetic drug in the lipid phase and reducing its toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  •  CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) should be initiated, and 20% intralipid should be administered intravenously to treat LAST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CPR with sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is not the first-line treatment for LAST. While it can be used to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias caused by local anesthetic toxicity, it does not directly counteract the toxic effects on the central nervous system and is not as effective as intralipid.

 

Option C. CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a medication used to increase cardiac output and blood pressure in some situations, but it is not the primary treatment for LAST.

 

Option D. CPR with calcium: Calcium does not reverse the toxic effects of local anesthetic systemic toxicity. Therefore, it is not the appropriate treatment for this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition.
  • Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV
